messages.subject: Re: Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Cheers Jim, I though it was probably late Akasaka, whilst the theme was simular in the Bushû work, the type of work is as you say, very different. Thanks
messages.messageBody:
Cheers Jim, I though it was probably late Akasaka, whilst the theme
was simular in the Bushû work, the type of work is as you say, very
different.

Thanks again for taking the time.

Rich



> Rich,
> The appearance of the metal, the shape of the rim and your
description of the lamination bones in the edge all point to Akasaka.
The very small size and thin plate point toward later work. It's
later than Ron's Tadashige. Bushu Ito people did use that design, but
the metal and rim are different. The Mosle/Izzard Ito example is in
shakudo and the carving is of course very different despite sharing
the design.
>
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: holes und lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Thanks.  The earlier Aizu Shoami people did even better work with good quality shakudo, carving and inlay.  Sea life motifs were also popular at that
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Thanks. The earlier Aizu Shoami people did even better work with good quality shakudo, carving and inlay. Sea life motifs were also popular at that time.

Jim

jim et al,


picture of the clam close up has been posted, please take a look see.

The middle clam is actually shakudo + gold colored lines, due to
wear, it appears " pinkish ".

milt



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: holes und lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: ... whole plate might have been covered at some point. ... together.  I wonder if they were mounted together on some non-weapon object for display at some
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Milt,
> Yes, it looks like traces of black lacquer. I suppose that the
whole plate might have been covered at some point.
>
> It's a strangely shaped ana and even stranger to see three of them
together. I wonder if they were mounted together on some non-weapon
object for display at some point. If done in the late 19th or early
20th C, there could be a fairly good patina on the walls.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> please klick................
>
> http://tinyurl.com/4l8z9
>
>

jim et al,
disregarding the mokko shaped tsuba ( most likely mito , nara ? ),
what school do you think the geese and the clam belong to ?

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] holes und lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Yes, it looks like traces of black lacquer.  I suppose that the whole plate might have been covered at some point. It s a strangely shaped ana and even
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Yes, it looks like traces of black lacquer. I suppose that the whole plate might have been covered at some point.

It's a strangely shaped ana and even stranger to see three of them together. I wonder if they were mounted together on some non-weapon object for display at some point. If done in the late 19th or early 20th C, there could be a fairly good patina on the walls.

Jim



please klick................

http://tinyurl.com/4l8z9

kindly look at pic 073f, near the rim at 9 to 11 o'clock area. I see
traces of what looks like " lacquer ".
Is it possible in the edo days the whole flat surface was covered
with black lacquer ?

Also look at pic 072f.............
the " strange shape hole " appeared to be made same time as the other
holes ( kogai, kozuka ), I based this conclusion on the
rust/condition of the inside of the holes ( one reason NOT to clean
the holes ? ). There is evidence that the tsuba were actually
used/mounted.

All three tsuba came from the same source/collection, can we assumed
they are meant for a single weapon ( e.g. a socket yari ) , like the
samurai changed them like he changed cloths ?

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The appearance of the metal, the shape of the rim and your description of the lamination bones in the edge all point to Akasaka.  The very small size and
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The appearance of the metal, the shape of the rim and your description of the lamination bones in the edge all point to Akasaka. The very small size and thin plate point toward later work. It's later than Ron's Tadashige. Bushu Ito people did use that design, but the metal and rim are different. The Mosle/Izzard Ito example is in shakudo and the carving is of course very different despite sharing the design.

Jim



All, I had a tsuba arrive today, it is a lot better in hand than the
original images I purchased it from showed. There are fine running bones
all the way around the mimi, I am thinking Akasaka. Here are some pics.
Obviously modeled after Tadashige though there are a few Ito/Bushû
versions around as well.

Dimensions are 70mm x 68mm x 3mm

cheers all

Rich

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-front.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-back.jpg

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-detail.jpg



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: holes und lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Milt - Interesting tsuba with strange nakago ana. Why socket yari? They fit over the pole and I don t understand how the tsuba would be retained to it? I don t
messages.messageBody:
Milt -

Interesting tsuba with strange nakago ana. Why
socket yari? They fit over the pole and I don't
understand how the tsuba would be retained to it?
I don't have any other ideas of use either, so ....

Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich - Kind of thought that email didn t leave the box...been having a fit with that of late! Anyway, let s try this again. The attached is a picture from
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich -

Kind of thought that email didn't leave the box...been having a fit with that of late! Anyway, let's try this again. The attached is a picture from my friend in Chile, the photo I bought the stein off off. I'm heading out this weekend, but next week I'll take a better photo and post it on Yahoo photos for all to see. Needless to say, I was relieved to see this signature pass in Chicago. I felt it had to be okay (and Jim Gilbert agreed when I showed it to him in Tampa) but still, a relief.

Ron

From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 7:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?


Hi Ron, no, I didn't get it.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, thanks for that, yes that Tadashige ( or simular ) tsuba is in the Akasaka book. It is much finer work indeed. This one of mine is like a cross between
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron, thanks for that, yes that Tadashige ( or simular ) tsuba is in
the Akasaka book. It is much finer work indeed. This one of mine is like
a cross between the Ito/Bushû ones around in books ( 3 different ones
from memory ) and the Akasaka though I thought mine with the running
bones in the Mimi and the seppa dai's shape may be a lter Akasaka, a
students work or something. I don't think it's bushû.

A good score on your behalf too mate. Well done, can you post any pics
of your tsuba ?.

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Rich -
>
> Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this design signed
> Tadashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I have it
> here in front of me now to compare the work with your tsuba. While the
> design is the same, the work on mine is more delicate (?)--more
> piercing--and seems to "flow" more, if you know what I mean. The
> horse's hoofs on your tsuba are more "squared" and "bold" than the
> more naturally shaped hoofs on my tsuba. I just saw a similar tsuba
> (picture) just the other day that showed these rather boldly made
> hoofs and it was called something other than Akasaka, but for the life
> of me I don't recall where I saw this. Thought it was in the new
> Mosle' catalogue, but if so, I'm not finding it now. My tsuba came out
> of a large collection of tsuba sold in Santiago, Chile in 2003. That
> collection also had another similar "horse" tsuba that had these large
> hoofs like your new tsuba, but I didn't buy that one. Most of these
> 730-plus tsuba were bought up by Michael Zomber, so perhaps your's
> could be the one I saw. I'll check my records.
>
> Ron
> STL
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Very nice you do find some classy sukashi tsuba.  I believe that another list member has a very similar piece, and I know that I have seen other similar
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Very nice you do find some classy sukashi tsuba. I believe that another
list member has a very similar piece, and I know that I have seen other
similar pieces in auction catalogs and books. Now to just remember which ones.

Lou

messages.msgSnippet: That s it. Thanks Andres. Ron STL ... From: apedraza@valornewmedia.com To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 4:08 PM Subject: Re:

----- Original Message -----
From: apedraza@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 4:08 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?



Rich and Ron,

>...it was called something other than Akasaka, but for the life of me I don't recall where I saw this. Thought it was in the new Mosle' catalogue, but if so, I'm not finding it now.<

It is Item 97 in the new Mosle catalog, labeled as ITÕ MASANORI. Hope
that helps.

Best Regards,

Andres Pedraza

-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 12:08 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?



Rich -

Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this design signed
Tadashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I have it
here in front of me now to compare the work with your tsuba. While the
design is the same, the work on mine is more delicate (?)--more
piercing--and seems to "flow" more, if you know what I mean. The
horse's hoofs on your tsuba are more "squared" and "bold" than the more
naturally shaped hoofs on my tsuba. I just saw a similar tsuba
(picture) just the other day that showed these rather boldly made hoofs
and it was called something other than Akasaka, but for the life of me
I don't recall where I saw this. Thought it was in the new Mosle'
catalogue, but if so, I'm not finding it now. My tsuba came out of a
large collection of tsuba sold in Santiago, Chile in 2003. That
collection also had another similar "horse" tsuba that had these large
hoofs like your new tsuba, but I didn't buy that one. Most of these
730-plus tsuba were bought up by Michael Zomber, so perhaps your's
could be the one I saw. I'll check my records.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 2:13 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?


All, I had a tsuba arrive today, it is a lot better in hand than the
original images I purchased it from showed. There are fine running
bones
all the way around the mimi, I am thinking Akasaka. Here are some
pics.
Obviously modeled after Tadashige though there are a few Ito/Bushû
versions around as well.

Dimensions are 70mm x 68mm x 3mm

cheers all

Rich


http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-front.jpg


http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-back.jpg


http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-detail.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Rich - Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this design signed Tadashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I have it here in front of
messages.messageBody:
Rich -

Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this design signed Tadashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I have it here in front of me now to compare the work with your tsuba. While the design is the same, the work on mine is more delicate (?)--more piercing--and seems to "flow" more, if you know what I mean. The horse's hoofs on your tsuba are more "squared" and "bold" than the more naturally shaped hoofs on my tsuba. I just saw a similar tsuba (picture) just the other day that showed these rather boldly made hoofs and it was called something other than Akasaka, but for the life of me I don't recall where I saw this. Thought it was in the new Mosle' catalogue, but if so, I'm not finding it now. My tsuba came out of a large collection of tsuba sold in Santiago, Chile in 2003. That collection also had another similar "horse" tsuba that had these large hoofs like your new tsuba, but I didn't buy that one. Most of these 730-plus tsuba were bought up by Michael Zomber, so perhaps your's could be the one I saw. I'll check my records.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 30, 2004 2:13 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Akasaka tsuba ?


All, I had a tsuba arrive today, it is a lot better in hand than the
original images I purchased it from showed. There are fine running bones
all the way around the mimi, I am thinking Akasaka. Here are some pics.
Obviously modeled after Tadashige though there are a few Ito/Bushû
versions around as well.

Dimensions are 70mm x 68mm x 3mm

cheers all

Rich

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akasaka-Horse-back.jpg
